abstract.p: Mauriceis a novel that waits for the future (for completion, publication, and audience) but also looks nostagically to the past. This strange temporal location reflects a temporality basic to Forster's narrative structures and sexual identity: like philosophers who presently ascribe to the “tenseless theory of time,” Forster dispels identity among a tenseless order of moments, in a narrative structure that seeks likewise to trade “becoming” for a better order. InMaurice, such tactics as iterative seriality, overdetermined prolepsis, nonephiphany, and other modes of “detensing” give form to a version of homosexuality that would escape “identity,” with unusual implications for moderist temporality and narratological criticism. Forster's modernist time is eccentric for its interest in logical order; and the narratological criticism which would attend to his “tenseless” homosexual form must remember that it is often the combination of subversion and order that encourages the best narratological advances.

ref.mixed-citation: See Isherwood , Christopher and His Kind :“Almost every time they met, after this, they discussed the problem: how shouldMauriceend? […] He loved this continuous discussion, simply as a game”(127).

After meeting Mohammed, his Alexandrian lover, Forster wrote,“Wish I was writing the latter half ofMaurice. I now know so much more”( Furbank
II 40); and he described himself sitting on a hillside in Alexandria in 1918“as Maurice and Clive sat at Cambridge”(49).

Here I refer of course to Foucault and his claim that the nineteenth-century “persecution of the peripheral sexualities entailed anincorporation of perversionsand a newspecification of individuals” in which homosexuality went from being “a category of forbidden acts” to marking “a personage, a past, a case history” (43). Foucault's observation that the homosexual now had a “past,” and that his sexuality was now “everywhere present” in him, contributes to my sense that identity has a narrative temporality.

See for example Gérard Genette , Narrative Discourse
33-85.

That homosexuals in particular would end up in lunatic asylums atMaurice'smoment in history seems unlikely, butMauriceitself says so: when a distraught Maurice seeks advice from Dr. Jowitt, Maurice asks, “I say, in your rounds here, do you come across unspeakables of the Oscar Wilde sort?,” and Jowitt answers, “No, that's in the asylum work, thank God” (156).

That this fundamental, disciplinary distinction is at the heart of the dispute between the detensers and their opponents has been only implicitly recognized (see Oaklander ,“Experience” 344-45). Detensers and their opponents, it seems, are really different kinds of philosophers, despite their various efforts to reconcile the philosophical claims of reason and experience.

Bergson also opposes the “myth of passage,” but I nevertheless associatedurationwithbecoming, because Bergsonism seeks the truth of time inchange(see Bergson 's distinction between homogeneous time and pure duration, in Time and FreeWill
90-91).

Other relevant theories of tense exist: Ricoeur discusses Harold Weinrich's theory of the significance gap between grammatical tense and the time of lived experience, a gap that suggests that fiction's tenses always challenge those of nonfictional discourse ( Ricoeur II
66-76).Tenselessnessbetter captures the spirit of the gap Forster creates between his fiction and life's plots because of the way it suggests that the challenge is not necessarily “fictional.”

On Forster's pragmatism, see May, whose definition of the pragmatic as that “which looks forward and backwards at the same time, no less alert to utopian possibility than opportunistic with the past” is particularly relevant here (ix); “moralist of the possible” is John Cronin's phrase for Forster (“Publishable—But Worth It?,”in Gardner
458).

See Forster 's“Art for Art's Sake,”which also calls for a certain kind of “order” in form, for another version of the unique combination of attitudes at work here ( Two Cheers for Democracy
90,94).
Herman defines polychrony as “a mode of narration that purposely resists linearity by multiplying ways in which narrated events can be ordered” (76).
The term is D. A. Miller 's, in Bringing Out Roland Barthes (48-49).

The following observations aboutMaurice'sironic linearity attempt the rigor of similar points made by Susan Stanford Friedman in her work on the “lyric subversion” of plot in women's writing and Margaret Homans in her work on feminist theories of narrative. Both of these critics successfully question the equation of linearity with patriarchy, and explain exactly what is subversive about such things as “lyric strategies,” and the following observations aim at a similar rigor through their ultimate claim that the opposite of the linear, in Forster's case, is greater narrative order, rather than some freedom that only superficially conflates the political and the textual.

This refutation is not quite what Scott Nelson describes in his study of “narrative inversion” in Forster. Nelson holds that the homosexual text “inverts its very commercial narrative structure,” reorienting the structure of narrative seduction in order to “expose society's dominant narratives as homophobic and oppressive” (315). “Inversion” suggests a tendency too agonistic to match Forster's irony.

Mauricetherefore expresses Forster's well-known antipathy towards a decadent aestheticism, that for him went too far in “introduc[ing] the fallacy that only art matters” and in “overstress[ing] idiosyncracy and waywardness—the peacock-feather aspect—rather than order” ( Forster , Two Cheers
92). Here again Forster suggests that it isorderthat matters, rather than the style of liberation presumably indulged in the sexual identity he associates with “peacock-feathers.”

I borrow this term from Paul Fry 's“Non-Epiphany in Wordsworth”( A Defense of Poetry
91-107).

A brief reference to biography might help to explain how the denial of presence works in a moment like this one. Forster himself became aware of the homosexual possibility—or at least one homosexual possibility—in a very different way. As a boy in his second term at Kent house, Forster “figured in a sexual drama”: an older man molested him, giving Forster a shilling in exchange for fondling. What is interesting is how Forster recorded this event in his diary. As P. N. Furbank puts it, “Morgan made an entry in his diary <<Nothing>>, to remind himself that there had been something” ( Furbank
I 38). Here, at an early moment, is that effacement of the present that allows the past to communicate with the future; making “nothing” thereminderof something, Forster already exhibits that detachment that will not give Maurice affirmative sexual awakening.

These observations about the relation between closure and the narrative line owe a debt to D. A. Miller 's theory (in Narrative and Its Discontents ) of the conflict between “closure” and the “narratable” and to Joseph Boone's sense of the way that untraditional endings bleed backwards.
